Menu

Children may present with symptoms that vary in severity

Rickets and osteomalacia are the underlying sources of symptoms that will progress throughout adulthood1-3,6

Symptoms of XLH such as bowed legs and lower extremity deformities begin to manifest in early childhood, at the onset of weight-bearing.1-3

SKELETAL DEFECTS

Chronic hypophosphatemia leads to defective growth plate development and bone mineralization4; children may present with:

Rickets and osteomalacia

  • Rickets is a disease in children characterized by abnormal mineralization of the bones as well as defective calcification of the cartilage growth plate at the epiphyses4
  • Osteomalacia is failure of mineralization of newly formed bone matrix4

Lower extremity deformities, including leg bowing, knock-knees, windswept deformities as well as short stature (predominant skeletal outcomes due to rickets and osteomalacia)1

Pain, which may result from bearing weight on weak bones and misaligned joints5

Craniosynotosis, which is the premature fusion of the sutures in the skull2,3

“The specific tests that puts us in the realm of XLH are serum phosphorus levels and in particular, urinary phosphate excretion.”

—Dr. Thomas Carpenter, XLH expert

Currently, there are no FDA-approved therapies to treat XLH.

Understanding the strategies to symptom management in children and adults with XLH can help you provide better care for patients.

Understand how to diagnose XLH
